question.title: Location of an object in memory using Java?

node.contents: Regarding your edit: are you trying to test if ASLR is more effective *for Java applications* in Windows 7, or just trying to test of ASLR is more effective *for applications in general*? If the former, then I posit that it is equally ineffective in all cases; if the latter, then Java is the wrong language to be using for such a test.

astNode.text: Regarding your edit: are you trying to test if ASLR is more effective *for Java applications* in Windows 7, or just trying to test of ASLR is more effective *for applications in general*? If the former, then I posit that it is equally ineffective in all cases; if the latter, then Java is the wrong language to be using for such a test.

node.contents: For all applications in General.

astNode.text: For all applications in General.

node.contents: Then you should be doing your test in C or another close-to-the-metal language, not in Java, which tries to be as far away from the actual operating system as possible.

astNode.text: Then you should be doing your test in C or another close-to-the-metal language, not in Java, which tries to be as far away from the actual operating system as possible.

node.contents: I used a simple test code and created an object in Java.

astNode.text: I used a simple test code and created an object in Java.

node.contents: I used the System.identityHashCode function to get the roughly equivalent address. Please see this question I asked for more context: Click Here

astNode.text: I used the System.identityHashCode function to get the roughly equivalent address. Please see this question I asked for more context: Click Here

node.contents: Now the question is, how do I know the above numbers generated are caused by ASLR. I am using Windows 7 and cannot switch ASLR off.

astNode.text: Now the question is, how do I know the above numbers generated are caused by ASLR. I am using Windows 7 and cannot switch ASLR off.

node.contents: In other words if ASLR is switched off do you think I will get the same number generated each time I run the code?

astNode.text: In other words if ASLR is switched off do you think I will get the same number generated each time I run the code?

node.contents: Sample code I used:

astNode.text: Sample code I used:

elements.contents: // public class HashCodeTest { public int hashCode() { return 0xDEADBEEF; } public static void main(String[] argv) { HashCodeTest o1 = new HashCodeTest(); System.out.println("First: " + o1); System.out.println("Using System.identityHashCode():"); System.out.println("First: " + System.identityHashCode(o1)); } }

units.rawText: // public class HashCodeTest { public int hashCode() { return 0xDEADBEEF; } public static void main(String[] argv) { HashCodeTest o1 = new HashCodeTest(); System.out.println("First: "+ o1); System.out.println("Using System.identityHashCode():"); System.out.println("First: "+ System.identityHashCode(o1)); } }

node.contents: What am I trying to accomplish? I want to see if Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is more effective in Windows 7 than in Windows Vista I want to plot a frequency distribution curve or use some other statistical tools on the data to see if it is more predictable in one OS compared to the other for ALL applications in general.

node.contents: @Paulo - see my answer ...

node.contents: @Paulo: The documentation says that it has integer mapping of memory location. " As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required by the JavaTM programming language.) "

astNode.text: @Paulo: The documentation says that it has integer mapping of memory location. " As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required by the JavaTM programming language.) "

node.contents: @redmave: have a look at the last phrase - **this implementation technique is not required by the Java programming language**. It might be, but does not have to be. In your example it might be some direct mapping of memory addresses, but as I explained in my answer, it can't always be done this way, so you should not rely on this. Of course, in a normal program you don't need this property, you only need the first sentence. For the applications in your special problem, the answer from Stephen seems good enough.

In your example it might be some direct mapping of memory addresses, but as I explained in my answer, it can't always be done this way, so you should not rely on this. Of course, in a normal program you don't need this property, you only need the first sentence. For the applications in your special problem, the answer from Stephen seems good enough.

node.contents: In general, in Java the identityHashCode() function does not specify anything about memory addresses. The only specified thing is that these numbers are constant over the whole lifetime of an object, and that they are different for different objects as much as possible.

astNode.text: In general, in Java the identityHashCode() function does not specify anything about memory addresses. The only specified thing is that these numbers are constant over the whole lifetime of an object, and that they are different for different objects as much as possible.

node.contents:
• On 64-bit VMs with enough memory you can create more than 2^32 objects at once, thus even the second condition can not mean "always different for different objects".

  • Modern Sun VMs are using a generational garbage collector, which means that objects are moved during their lifetime. The memory address then changes, while the identity hash code has to be the same - thus it can't be always the memory address.

astNode.text:
• On 64-bit VMs with enough memory you can create more than 2^32 objects at once, thus even the second condition can not mean "always different for different objects".

  • Modern Sun VMs are using a generational garbage collector, which means that objects are moved during their lifetime. The memory address then changes, while the identity hash code has to be the same - thus it can't be always the memory address.

node.contents: Thus, you can't rely on anything beside the condition mentioned above. On some VMs (especially old ones with non-moving garbage collectors) the number might be something which could be converted in C to the memory address (or the initial address when the object was created), but another valid implementation would be pseudo-random numbers given on object creation, or a simple counter.

astNode.text: Thus, you can't rely on anything beside the condition mentioned above. On some VMs (especially old ones with non-moving garbage collectors) the number might be something which could be converted in C to the memory address (or the initial address when the object was created), but another valid implementation would be pseudo-random numbers given on object creation, or a simple counter.

node.contents: Address space layout randomization (ASLR) is:

astNode.text: Address space layout randomization (ASLR) is:

node.contents:
• not necessary for Java applications
  • unlikely to be helpful for Java applications
  • actively defeated by the memory management techniques of many JVM implementations

astNode.text:
• not necessary for Java applications
  • unlikely to be helpful for Java applications
  • actively defeated by the memory management techniques of many JVM implementations

node.contents: Sun's JVM, for example, will allocate a large section of virtual memory at startup time (presumably using the OS heap functions to grab a single large block), and then proceed to manage that memory as its own heap in a very well-known way. That is, the Eden, Survivor spaces, Tenured heap, and PermGen are all laid out the same way, and I'm pretty certain ASLR can't do anything about that.

astNode.text: Sun's JVM, for example, will allocate a large section of virtual memory at startup time (presumably using the OS heap functions to grab a single large block), and then proceed to manage that memory as its own heap in a very well-known way. That is, the Eden, Survivor spaces, Tenured heap, and PermGen are all laid out the same way, and I'm pretty certain ASLR can't do anything about that.

node.contents: However, the hacking techniques that ASLR is attempting to prevent simply aren't possible in Java anyway, for several reasons:

astNode.text: However, the hacking techniques that ASLR is attempting to prevent simply aren't possible in Java anyway, for several reasons:

node.contents:
1. Most JVM implementations frequently copy objects from one location to another in memory. Therefore, it is impossible to predict with any certainty where any object will be at any point in time.

  2. It is not possible for Java code to allocate arbitrary-sized objects on the Java stack, so stack overruns are not possible.

  3. It is impossible to subvert the Java Memory Model from within Java code; the only code for which this is possible is platform-native code invoked via JNI. (Or sun.misc.Unsafe, which is an unsafe wrapper for basically the same thing.) Therefore, as long as you use the Java SecurityManager features correctly, no rogue process is capable of writing to any dangerous memory location anyway.

astNode.text:
1. Most JVM implementations frequently copy objects from one location to another in memory. Therefore, it is impossible to predict with any certainty where any object will be at any point in time.

  2. It is not possible for Java code to allocate arbitrary-sized objects on the Java stack, so stack overruns are not possible.

  3. It is impossible to subvert the Java Memory Model from within Java code; the only code for which this is possible is platform-native code invoked via JNI. (Or sun.misc.Unsafe, which is an unsafe wrapper for basically the same thing.) Therefore, as long as you use the Java SecurityManager features correctly, no rogue process is capable of writing to any dangerous memory location anyway.

node.contents: Perhaps you should describe what you are trying to accomplish and why you think that ASLR will help you accomplish it. I'm pretty sure that (a) ASLR isn't having any effect on your Java programs, and (b) that's OK, because you don't really want it anyway.

astNode.text: Perhaps you should describe what you are trying to accomplish and why you think that ASLR will help you accomplish it. I'm pretty sure that (a) ASLR isn't having any effect on your Java programs, and (b) that's OK, because you don't really want it anyway.

node.contents: @redmave - maybe, but I can still see a lot of repetition in the first 2 or 3 lines. You'd need to sort / count those numbers to see how much randomization is actually occurring.

astNode.text: @redmave - maybe, but I can still see a lot of repetition in the first 2 or 3 lines. You'd need to sort / count those numbers to see how much randomization is actually occurring.

node.contents: I was the person who suggested that the OP should use identityHashcode() values as ersatz memory addresses. My idea is that, though they are not real memory addresses, they are based on the memory address of the object in question when identityHashcode() is first called ... on a typical JVM implementation. This makes them a reasonable proxy for real memory addresses, for the purposes of THIS experiment.

astNode.text: I was the person who suggested that the OP should use identityHashcode() values as ersatz memory addresses. My idea is that, though they are not real memory addresses, they are based on the memory address of the object in question when identityHashcode() is first called ... on a typical JVM implementation. This makes them a reasonable proxy for real memory addresses, for the purposes of THIS experiment.

node.contents: My answer to the OP is that those results strongly suggest that ASLR is either not enabled, or it is not effective in randomizing the actual addresses of Java objects.

astNode.text: My answer to the OP is that those results strongly suggest that ASLR is either not enabled, or it is not effective in randomizing the actual addresses of Java objects.

node.contents: I would expect a certain amount of natural unpredictability in the object address because of non-deterministic factors in the JVM bootstrap sequence. That is why you are seeing 3 or 4 different hashcode values for that object in different runs. However, the fact that you are seeing certain values repeatedly strongly suggests that there is no systematic randomization happening. In other words, no ASLR.

astNode.text: I would expect a certain amount of natural unpredictability in the object address because of non-deterministic factors in the JVM bootstrap sequence. That is why you are seeing 3 or 4 different hashcode values for that object in different runs. However, the fact that you are seeing certain values repeatedly strongly suggests that there is no systematic randomization happening. In other words, no ASLR.

node.contents: Strictly speaking, we should examine the JVM source code to check that identityHashcode is really reporting something that would change if ASLR was effective ... but I don't have time right now.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: (FWIW: I agree with other people who have answered / commented that ASLR is not needed for Java anyway. Modulo some unpatched bug in the JVM native code, a Java JVM simply does not allow a sandboxed Java program to inject executable (native) code. And even a privileged Java program could only do this via a custom native library.)

astNode.text: (FWIW: I agree with other people who have answered / commented that ASLR is not needed for Java anyway. Modulo some unpatched bug in the JVM native code, a Java JVM simply does not allow a sandboxed Java program to inject executable (native) code. And even a privileged Java program could only do this via a custom native library.)
